class PinÂ¶

Example

Simple read or control pin:

# Import Pin class
from robot_hat import Pin

# Create Pin object with numeric pin numbering and default input pullup enabled
d0 = Pin(16, Pin.IN, Pin.PULL_UP)
# Create Pin object with named pin numbering
d1 = Pin(25)

# read value
value0 = d0.value()
value1 = d1.value()
print(value0, value1)

# write value
d0.value(1) # force input to output
d1.value(0)

# set pin high/low
d0.high()
d1.off()

Interrupt:

# Import Pin class
from bella_hat.pin import Pin

# set interrupt
led = Pin(16, Pin.OUT)
switch = Pin(25, Pin.IN, Pin.PULL_DOWN)
def onPressed(chn):
    led.value(not switch.value())
switch.irq(handler=onPressed, trigger=Pin.IRQ_RISING_FALLING)

while True:
    pass

API

class bella_hat.pin.Pin(pin, mode=None, pull=None, *args, **kwargs)Â¶

Bases: _Basic_class

Pin manipulation class

OUT = 1Â¶

Pin mode output

IN = 2Â¶

Pin mode input

PULL_UP = 17Â¶

Pin internal pull up

PULL_DOWN = 18Â¶

Pin internal pull down

PULL_NONE = NoneÂ¶

Pin internal pull none

IRQ_FALLING = 33Â¶

Pin interrupt falling

IRQ_RISING = 34Â¶

Pin interrupt falling

IRQ_RISING_FALLING = 35Â¶

Pin interrupt both rising and falling

__init__(pin, mode=None, pull=None, *args, **kwargs)Â¶

Initialize a pin

Parameters:

  • pin (int/str) â pin number of Raspberry Pi

  • mode (int) â pin mode(IN/OUT)

  • pull (int) â pin pull up/down(PUD_UP/PUD_DOWN/PUD_NONE)

setup(mode, pull=None)Â¶

Setup the pin

Parameters:

  • mode (int) â pin mode(IN/OUT)

  • pull (int) â pin pull up/down(PUD_UP/PUD_DOWN/PUD_NONE)

dict(_dict=None)Â¶

Parameters:

_dict (dict) â pin dictionary, leave it empty to get the dictionary

dict

irq(handler, trigger, bouncetime=200, pull=None)Â¶

Set the pin interrupt

Parameters:

  • handler (function) â interrupt handler callback function

  • trigger (int) â interrupt trigger(RISING, FALLING, RISING_FALLING)

  • bouncetime (int) â interrupt bouncetime in miliseconds
